Article.ArticleTitle: Association between short-term exposure to ambient air pollutants and the risk of tuberculosis outpatient visits: A time-series study in Hefei, China.

AbstractText: The current evidence has presented mixed results between air pollutants exposure and the progression of tuberculosis (TB). The purpose of this study was to explore the association between short-term exposure to air pollutants and the risk of TB outpatient visits in Hefei, China.

Time-series analysis was used to assess the effect of short-term exposure to ambient air pollutants on the risk of TB outpatient visits. A Poisson generalized linear regression model combined with a distributed lag non-linear model (DLNM) was applied to explore the association. The effects of different gender (male, female), age (≤65 years old, >65 years old) and season (cold season, warm season) on the risk of TB were investigated by stratified analysis. Sensitivity analyses were conducted to test the robustness of our findings.

A total of 22,749 active TB cases were identified from November 1, 2013 to December 31, 2018 in Hefei. The overall exposure-response curve showed that the concentration of particulate matter with aerodynamic diameter less than 2.5 μm (PM<sub>2.5</sub>) and nitrogen dioxide (NO<sub>2</sub>) exposure were positively correlated with the risk of TB outpatient visits, while ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) and sulfur dioxide (SO<sub>2</sub>) exposure were negatively correlated with the risk of TB outpatient visits. The maximum lag-specific and cumulative relative risk (RR) of TB outpatient visits were 1.057 [95%CI: 1.002-1.115, lag 3 day] and 1.559 (95%CI: 1.057-2.300, lag 13 days) for each 10 μg/m³ increase in PM<sub>2.5</sub>; 1.026 (95% CI: 1.008-1.044, lag 0 day) and 1.559 (95%CI: 1.057-2.300, lag 07 days) for each 10 μg/m³ increase in NO<sub>2</sub>; 0.866 (95% CI: 0.801-0.935, lag 5 day) and 0.852 (95%CI: 1.01-1.11, lag 0-14 days) for each 10 μg/m³ increase in SO<sub>2</sub> in the single-pollutant model. There was only a negative association between O<sub>3</sub> exposure and the cumulative risk of TB outpatient visits (RR = 0.960, 95%CI: 0.936-0.984, lag 07 days). Stratified analyses showed that the effects of SO<sub>2</sub> and O<sub>3</sub> exposure were different between warm and cold seasons. The effect of NO<sub>2</sub> exposure remained statistically significant in male, younger, and cold season subgroups. Besides, elderly people are more susceptible to PM<sub>2.5</sub> exposure.

This study suggests that exposure to PM<sub>2.5</sub>, NO<sub>2</sub>, SO<sub>2</sub>, and O<sub>3</sub> are associated with the risk of TB outpatient visits. Seasonal variation may have a greater impact on the risk of TB outpatient visits compared with gender and age.
